awd_titl_txt: Sensory-Biased Working Memory & Attention Networks in the Human Brain
awd_abstract_narration:
Abstract

Humans experience the world via multiple sensory modalities --  we see, we hear, and we touch. Each sensory modality has unique strengths and weaknesses in its ability to represent the world around us. Our minds are able to flexibly recruit visual or auditory brain structures when their strengths correspond to the task at hand. In addition, our experience at any moment depends both on sensory input and on working memory and attention mechanisms in the brain. These mechanisms have very limited capacities, which in turn limit cognition. The overarching goal of this project is to examine the human brain mechanisms that support attention and working memory in vision, hearing, and touch. The research team will perform functional MRI experiments to study the brain activity of healthy adults while they perform demanding sensory working memory tasks. Preliminary studies by the research group suggest that there are extensive brain networks, extending into the frontal lobes of the cerebral cortex, that are specialized for each sensory modality, as well as a shared network that supports and unifies these three senses. The current research program will examine individual differences in working memory performance and brain network organization. It will also develop advanced computational models that can predict the functional organization of an individual's brain from their unique pattern or 'fingerprint' of brain connectivity. The project will facilitate other research efforts through the dissemination of new models and computational tools, and will recruit and train young scientists, including members of groups that are under-represented in STEM, in cognitive neuroscience research.

This proposal has 4 primary intellectual goals: (1) identify the fine-scale organization of tactile, visual, auditory, and modality-independent attention & working memory (WM) regions within human cerebral cortex; (2) reveal the specificity of coding of WM information across cortical regions for each modality; (3) detail the network organization of attention & WM circuits; and (4) test hypotheses about content-specific WM mechanisms and cross-modality WM coding. Individual subject fMRI analyses permit fine-scale observation of distinct functional regions. Drawing on subject-specific maps of cortical organization, the research group will re-examine the highly debated question of which brain structures support stimulus-specific working memory for each modality. It will investigate the specificity of sensory modality biased regions by examining functional networks in the resting-state within individual participants. The research team will leverage its findings to probe these networks in 1200 subjects from the Human Connectome Project dataset. The research group will also test and validate a machine-learning approach, Connectome Fingerprinting, for predicting the location of modality-specific working memory regions in individual brains from their unique functional connectome. Vision excels in coding spatial information, but codes timing less reliably; conversely, the auditory system performs high-fidelity temporal coding but coarse spatial coding. The research team has observed cross-modal recoding of WM information into cortical structures that prefer the 'appropriate modality' - auditory spatial WM recruits visual-biased regions and visual temporal WM recruits auditory-biased regions. To probe content-specific WM mechanisms, the researchers will examine interactions between sensory modality WM and space/time WM. The research group hypothesizes that visual and spatial WM stores are distinct, but that auditory and timing WM stores are shared. Collectively, these studies will elucidate the human brain networks and mechanisms that support sensory working memory.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Our research team investigated the functional organization of attention and working memory mechanisms in the human brain, using functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) and behavioral studies. Perceptual and cognitive functions depend heavily on: 1. our abilities to attentionally focus on important information and filter out irrelevant information; and 2. Our ability to retain this information in working memory for the duration of the cognitive tasks that we are performing. Prior work has demonstrated that a network of lateral frontal and posterior parietal cortical regions support attention and working memory. Much prior work suggests that attention and working memory networks are ‘domain-general’ or ‘multiple-demand,’ meaning that the same networks support attention and working memory for all types of information. However, prior work from our laboratory and others indicates that finer-scale functional organization may exist in which numerous brain regions play more highly specified roles, strongly supporting attention and working memory for particular types of information (e.g., sensory modality or space-based or time-based). Increasing our scientific understanding of the specific functions that brain regions perform in attention and working memory is important to advancing our understanding of cognitive brain development in children, cognitive mechanisms in healthy and aging adults, and the basis of a broad range of neurological disorders that impact cognition and/or perception.


The specific goals of our project were to: 1. Functionally map the brain regions that demonstrate a preference for supporting attention and working memory in each of three sensory modalities – vision, hearing (audition), and touch (somatosensation); 2. Functionally map the brain regions that support attention and working memory in all 3 sensory modalities and thus function in a multi-sensory and/or multiple-demand capacity; 3. Examine the network connectivity of these brain regions; and 4. Compare and contrast the working memory functioning of these regions for spatial and time-based (temporal) working memory tasks.


Our studies revealed three specific networks that each preferentially supported a particular sensory modality – vision, audition, and somatosensation, respectively. Each sensory-biased attention and working memory network consisted of multiple cortical regions spanning frontal and posterior cortex. The sensory-biased regions are relatively small and somewhat anatomically variable in their location across individuals but are reliably observed within an individual and adhere to a common functional architecture across individuals. This fine-scale functional organization is best observed by performing analyses at the level of individual subjects; prior investigations have primarily relied on group-averaging techniques which necessarily blur fine-scale functional organization and can yield an artifactual finding of ‘multiple-demand’ representations, when in fact there are functional distinct regions that simply lie next to each other. Additionally, we observed evidence for a network of ‘multiple-demand’ attention and working memory regions. While some multiple-demand regions reside in anatomically distinct regions, such as the anterior insula and the pre-supplementary motor area, several others lie near sensory-biased regions. Intriguingly, multiple-demand regions typically exhibited partial overlap with the anterior or lateral portions of visual-biased regions, with a clear shift in the centers of the regions; however, multiple-demand regions did not overlap with auditory-biased regions and only exhibited partial overlap with one somatosensory-biased region. This suggests that the visual modality may have privileged access to and/or control of the domain-general mechanisms of attention and working memory; however, further investigations will be needed to better understand this functional relationship.


We further observed that visual-biased cortical regions were interspersed with auditory-biased and somatosensory-biased regions, yet formed networks over long distances with other regions that shared their sensory modality preference. The multiple-demand regions were also observed to form strong functional networks. The multiple-demand network exhibited greater functional connectivity with the visual-biased network than with the other two sensory-biased networks.


Our examinations of space-based (spatial) and time-based (temporal) working memory utilized spatio-temporal sequences in each of three sensory modalities. Within a modality, the stimuli for spatial and temporal working memory were the same, but the remembered component varied. We observed that spatial working memory, for all three sensory modalities, preferentially recruited the visual-biased network, while temporal working memory, for all three sensory modalities, preferentially recruited the auditory-biased network. That is, the functional brain networks that were recruited dynamically shifted with the nature of the task. In the realm of perception, vision is regarded as having the highest fidelity for spatial information, while audition has the highest fidelity for timing. It appears that the networks that are best suited to preserving the relevant information (spatial or temporal) are recruited to meet the task demands. Intriguingly, we also observed that the anterior hippocampus, which was not recruited in our standard working memory tasks, was strongly recruited in both spatial and temporal working memory tasks. This finding contributes to an on-going scientific debate about the possible role of the hippocampus in working memory, suggesting that anterior hippocampus may play a key role in spatio-temporal binding of stimuli into events or episodes.
